results.name: Square array A(n,d): overwrite with zero the digit at position d from right (indicating radix d+2) in the factorial base representation of n, then convert back to decimal, read by descending antidiagonals as A(0,0), A(0,1), A(1,0), A(0,2), A(1,1), A(2,0), etc.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..7259; the first 120 antidiagonals of array
Index entries for sequences related to factorial base representation
example: Columns 0-4 of rows 0 - 24 of the array:
0, 0, 0, 0, 0, ... [No matter which digit of zero we clear, it stays zero forever]
0, 1, 1, 1, 1  ... [When clearing the least significant digit (pos. 0) of one, "1", we get zero, and clearing any other digit past the most significant digit keeps one as one]
2, 0, 2, 2, 2, ... [Clearing the least significant digit of 2, "10", doesn't affect it, but clearing the digit-1 zeros the whole number].

2, 1, 3, 3, 3, ... [Clearing the least significant factorial base digit of 3 ("11") gives "10", 2, clearing the digit-1 gives "01" = 1, and clearing any digit past the most significant keeps "11" as it is, 3].
program: (define (A275730bi n c) (let loop ((z 0) (n n) (m 2) (f 1) (c c)) (let ((d (modulo n m))) (cond ((zero? n) z) ((zero? c) (loop z (/ (- n d) m) (+ 1 m) (* f m) (- c 1))) (else (loop (+ z (* f d)) (/ (- n d) m) (+ 1 m) (* f m) (- c 1)))))))
xref: Can be used when computing A275732 and A275736.
